subject: Re: JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: ... You re right, generics make sense here; I posted my generified version in the forum mentioned before
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@m...> wrote:
> ...
> I really like assertThat. I've reimplemented it at least twice to take
> advantage of
> generics:
>
> public void <T> assertThat (T obj, Constraint<T> constraint);
>
> That said, it's a little heavy-weight if you want to define many new
> constraints, and I still need to find the right balance.
> ...

You're right, generics make sense here; I posted my generified version
in the forum mentioned before
(http://saloon.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic&f=68&t=000944).

Why do you think that this aproach is heavy weight? What would be less
heavy weight?


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> ...
> I would prefer @BeforeTest, @BeforeSuite and their @After* companions.
> ...

I agree, it reads better and is more exact in its meaning. What do the
other readers (especially those who haven't responded yet) think about
using these names?


While browsing through the latest source code of JUnit two more
questions turned up in my head:
1) Why does junit.framework.Assert still define assertEquals for
boolean, int, long etc. (autoboxing could do that; in fact, deleting
those methods doesn't produce any errors)?
2) Why isn't java.lang.AssertionError used instead of
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError?

Thanks for your patience,
Michael Herrmann
